title: Great lights, but unreliable setup
text:
I really do love the lights offered by LIFX, I switched from Phillips hue and fitted my whole apartment with them since I needed smaller bulbs than what hue offered. I have nothing bad to say about their products *after* the setup process.
Trying to setup these lights was not fun, especially when you‚Äôre setting up 15+ at the same time, and it honestly made me miss the fact that Phillips hue uses a hub on Ethernet instead of connecting each individual bulb to WiFi and HomeKit. After around 8 bulbs were setup the process became extremely unreliable as if the network was saturated despite the fact I had the lights on a separate access point with a special IoT WiFi network. 
This might be my fault or my router but hey the app asked for a rating after hours of googling and resetting bulbs over and over because HomeKit is really good at having ‚Äúunexpected errors occur‚Äù

TL;DR these lights are great but be warned your experience may suffer with too many.

title: Good design, but often unresponsive.
text:
I know a lot of people don‚Äôt like the new UI, but it‚Äôs honestly a bit clearer, and looks much better. I only fumbled for a few days, accidentally turning my room mates lights on because of the new swiping features. Once you relearn though, it feels like it was well thought out. 

As far as functionality, it‚Äôs a bit wonky. To transition to a scene I want, I have to tap back and forth between two different scenes, as if I have to wake up the lights from a rest mode. Also, I‚Äôm aware tiles have been discontinued, at least for now, but the app tends to not have total control over them anymore. I have 3 connected in a straight line. Unless I use a premade scene (and even then sometimes), they will randomly switch to morph. No matter what color I set them to (aside from ‚Äúoff‚Äù), they always end up on morph after about 3-5 minutes of whatever I had just set it to. 

Sometimes while browsing colors in the color wheel, you‚Äôll experience the whole wheel spin around incredibly quickly, as if it‚Äôs attempting to catch up. Something about this version communicates with the lights much slower than before. This is all minor though, as it only takes a few seconds to troubleshoot and fix any problem.

title: Terrible app
text:
The new app is a complete failure in functionality. What used to be a very straightforward operation in turning lights on or off has become twice as cumbersome with this revised app. The addition of fake line drawings of your different rooms is utterly pointless and only succeeds in filling up the screen so that you‚Äôre forced to scroll far too long if you have more than one room set up. The action of turning lights on or off is also much slower and unresponsive with the new app while adjusting individual lights in a group has become very difficult. 

The new app has a greater emphasis on effects such as making all the lights in your house flicker like a candle or perform an epilepsy-inducing strobe. Pointless. Classic case of ‚Äòcan we do this‚Äô instead of ‚Äòshould we do this‚Äô. 

The app development team at LIFX should be ashamed at their lack of user testing. Clearly they‚Äôve been given too much freedom to be ‚Äòartistic‚Äô without any checks on actual usability. I hate this new app and every loyal customer of LIFX will too. I wish I went with the Hue.

title: Solid App but The Apple Watch Version is Still Bad

I usually want to use the watch for my light switches because it‚Äôs always on my wrist but it‚Äôs always super laggy and takes 5-10 seconds before I can turn the lights on and off with it, which defeats the convenience and speed of having your light controls on the watch. Once it loads up the switches sometimes don‚Äôt work or seem to get reversed so off becomes on. 3/5 stars might seem harsh for just the watch app issues but when I am spending $40 per bulb and up to $250 for some of their lights, I expect a perfected and responsive app. I would suggest LIFX adds a 2nd watch widget besides just a button to open the app. If they added a widget that just acted as a switch for a selected group of lights it would go a long way to make the watch experience better.

title: Lights, amazing. App, not so much.
text:
I actually emailed LIFX a pretty lengthy email about this (with no response) but here‚Äôs an abbreviated version.

The lights themselves are amazing. Really love them. No questions there about whether I‚Äôd purchase again or continue to because I will.

The app on the other hand is barely useable. Here‚Äôs a short list of grievances:

- Effects can‚Äôt be saved with scenes. This is crazy. Why can I not save the exact setup I want with effects included? I ALWAYS want a specific effect with my studio lights. How hard is this to implement?

- Effects can‚Äôt be run without app being on. This is also aggravating for someone who is OCD about constantly quitting apps that aren‚Äôt in use by habit.

- Much larger overall issue but the ergonomics hierarchy here is so so wrong. The menu layouts are terrible and it takes many steps to achieve some things that should only take a few clicks. Example: scenes should be stored with built in color palettes. Instead I have to adjust my light, go to another tab, select the scene, go into the scene, assign it, and then go back out. How about, select light, select scene..... done.

- Google Nest integration is broken because of nest/google login issue

Those are just to name a few... this app needs a total overhaul even though you guys put work into the new one. It‚Äôs truly objectively bad design.

Love the lights tho!

title: Good update, but there‚Äôs a bug...
text:
I‚Äôve been testing the new app since it was in beta. The whole time I never found a bug. Now that it‚Äôs released, here one is! At first I thought I was going crazy, but I was able to repeat multiple times.

Here is what I found:
If you set a schedule and change the time from a static hour/minute to sunrise, and then offset the time (in my case, it was 1 hour before), once you hit SAVE, sunrise switches to SUNSET. You have to go back in and re-select Sunrise and then hit save again and it will save correctly.

Now for my general review:
Other than the bug I found, I really think this new app is a huge improvement over the previous version. It‚Äôs a lot easier to manage entire groups, set schedules, and the timeline view really helps see the order that everything is happening.  IDK why so many people are finding this version so difficult to work with. If you organize your lights into groups, changes to multiple lights are a lot easier.  Maybe if you only have a small number of lights it‚Äôs more cumbersome, but I‚Äôve got 15 and on the old app it took me forever to get everything the way I wanted it.  

But that‚Äôs just me. To each their own!

title: How to connect your light to home WiFi (IPhone)
text:
So I‚Äôve had this bulb for a few years and it‚Äôs been great. The only downside is trying to connect it to a new WiFi or reconnecting it after changing your WiFi password. However I‚Äôve figured out how to connect to my WiFi in 1 or 2 tries with a simple trick (IPhone). 

1. Go to your phone settings and set your home WiFi to ‚ÄúAuto-Join‚Äù. 

2. Press home and open LIFX app and follow directions to connect your light. When you reach the point where it asks you to select your home WiFi. Select the first ‚ÄúWPA(most common)‚Äù or whatever your home WiFi type is 

3. Enter your user & password. (Before pressing connect make sure your WiFi setting is open on your phone)

4. Press connect and immediately double tap the home button to switch to WiFi setting screen.

5. Your phone should connect to your home WiFi

6. Immediately switch back to lifx app, and your phone should connect to your light.

Hope this helps
